segments.en: Hello, everyone, and welcome to EnglishPod.
My name is Marco.
My name is Catherine, and you've probably heard us talking a little bit about small talk the past few weeks.
segments.cn: 我叫Catherine，过去几周你们可能听到我们谈论了一些关于寒暄的话题。

segments.en: We have another episode about small talk, and we're going to teach you some things that you can say to people when you haven't seen them or maybe even met them before.
segments.cn: 我们有另一集关于寒暄的节目，我们将教你一些在没有见过或可能甚至没有见过的人面前可以说的话。

segments.en: That's right.
Today we're going to talk to a stranger, so we're going to talk very briefly about some casual topic.
segments.cn: 今天我们要和一个陌生人交谈，所以我们将简要讨论一些随意的话题。

segments.en: And so let's jump into the dialogue and see what happens.
segments.cn: 那么让我们进入对话，看看会发生什么。

segments.en: Excuse me, is this seat taken?
No, please, feel free.
Thanks a lot.
Do you work in Shanghai?
Yes, I do.
How about you?
No, I'm a tourist.
This place is amazing.
It's much bigger than I imagined and much more exciting.
segments.cn: 比我想象的要大得多，也更令人兴奋。

segments.en: There's so much to see here.
segments.cn: 这里有很多东西可以看。

segments.en: You can say that again.
It's much more modern than people imagine.
segments.cn: 这里比人们想象的要现代得多。

segments.en: Where are you from?
Well, let's see.
I'm from Kansas originally, a much quieter and more peaceful place than here, that's for sure.
segments.cn: 我最初来自堪萨斯，那是一个比这里安静得多、和平得多的地方，这一点是肯定的。

segments.en: But I'm living in Paris right now.
Oh, Paris.
Wonderful.
I'd love to visit sometime.
All right, we're back.
So now we're going to take a look at a lot of phrases on this occasion.
segments.cn: 现在我们将看看很多短语。

segments.en: So let's go for fluency builder part one.
segments.cn: 所以让我们开始流利表达的第一部分。

segments.en: Fluency builder.
All right, so the first phrase we have is a very common phrase if you're in a train or on a bus.
segments.cn: 好的，第一个短语是一个非常常见的短语，如果你在火车上或公交车上。

segments.en: You hear the phrase, is this seat taken?
segments.cn: 你会听到这个短语：这个座位有人吗？

segments.en: Right, so Michelle came up to the stranger and said, excuse me, is this seat taken?
segments.cn: 对，米歇尔走到陌生人面前说，抱歉，这个座位有人吗？

segments.en: That means is anybody sitting here?
segments.cn: 这意味着这里有人坐吗？

segments.en: It basically means can I sit here?
segments.cn: 基本上是问我可以坐这里吗？

segments.en: Right.
This is a very polite way of asking if you can sit down in the seat.
segments.cn: 这是一个非常礼貌的询问方式，问你是否可以坐下。

segments.en: You can also say it in a restaurant, at a movie theater, in a classroom.
segments.cn: 你也可以在餐厅、电影院、教室里这样说。

segments.en: So remember this one, this was a really, really common phrase.
segments.cn: 所以记住这个，这是一个非常非常常见的短语。

segments.en: So it's a very polite way of saying, can I sit down?
segments.cn: 所以这是一个非常礼貌的说法，问我可以坐下吗？

segments.en: That's right.
You're asking for permission basically.
segments.cn: 你基本上是在请求许可。

segments.en: Is the seat taken?
Because what if a person says, well, no, it's not.
segments.cn: 因为如果一个人说，不，没有人坐。

segments.en: Do you have to say, may I sit down?
segments.cn: 你需要说，我可以坐下吗？

segments.en: May I take a seat?
Well, if they say, I'm sorry someone is sitting here, that means that maybe they're waiting for a friend and then, no, you can't sit there.
segments.cn: 如果他们说，抱歉，有人坐在这里，那意味着他们可能在等朋友，那么不，你不能坐那里。

segments.en: Okay.
But if they say, sure, like in the dialogue, feel free, then you're really basically able to sit down no problem.
segments.cn: 但如果他们说，当然，就像对话中说的，随意，那么你基本上可以毫无问题地坐下。

segments.en: Right.
So the stranger answers by saying, no, please feel free.
segments.cn: 所以陌生人回答说，不，请随意。

segments.en: So he says, no, the seat is not taken.
segments.cn: 所以他说，不，这个座位没有人。

segments.en: Please feel free.
What does he say?
What does he mean by this?
Okay.
Feel free is a very unusual phrase in English, but one that you're gonna hear a lot.
segments.cn: 随意是一个在英语中非常不寻常的短语，但你会经常听到。

segments.en: It basically means do what you want to do.
segments.cn: 它基本上意味着做你想做的事。

segments.en: Okay.
Okay.
So if I want to sit down, I say, is this seat taken?
segments.cn: 所以如果我想坐下，我会说，这个座位有人吗？

segments.en: If you say, feel free, Marco, that means feel free to sit down.
segments.cn: 如果你说，随意，Marco，那意味着随意坐下。

segments.en: Okay.
So we can complete the sentence by saying, no, please feel free to sit down.
segments.cn: 所以我们可以完成这个句子，说，不，请随意坐下。

segments.en: But it's kind of stating the obvious.
You're saying basically feel free to do what you want.
segments.cn: 你基本上是在说随意做你想做的事。

segments.en: That's right.
But you could use it in other ways.
segments.cn: 但你可以用其他方式使用它。

segments.en: For example, hey Marco, are you using this pen right here?
segments.cn: 例如，嘿Marco，你在用这支笔吗？

segments.en: No, no, feel free.
That means feel free to use my pen.
segments.cn: 那意味着随意使用我的笔。

segments.en: Okay.
Very good.
And so then they started talking about what they do, where they work, and Michelle said, yes, I work in Shanghai.
segments.cn: 然后他们开始谈论他们的工作，米歇尔说，是的，我在上海工作。

segments.en: How about you?
Oh, how about you?
Now this is a really important construction.
segments.cn: 现在这是一个非常重要的结构。

segments.en: This is a really important phrase in English and I think a lot of people make mistakes with this.
segments.cn: 这是英语中一个非常重要的短语，我认为很多人对此会犯错误。

segments.en: So how about you means, do you work in Shanghai?
segments.cn: 所以你呢意味着，你在上海工作吗？

segments.en: I just said I work in Shanghai, but how about you?
segments.cn: 我刚才说我在上海工作，但你呢？

segments.en: Do you?
Right, exactly.
So that's saying, and you?
Do you work here?
Or and you?
What do you do?
How about you?
Now the common mistake with how about you, or using the construction how about, is that for some reason some people seem to think that it means, how is it?
segments.cn: 现在关于你呢的常见错误，或者使用你呢这个结构，是因为某些原因，有些人似乎认为它意味着，怎么样？

segments.en: So for example, if someone says, how about your weekend?
segments.cn: 所以例如，如果有人说，你周末怎么样？

segments.en: That's wrong.
No, we don't say that.
How was your weekend?
But in this case, how about you, always follows a statement.
segments.cn: 但在这种情况下，你呢，总是跟在一个陈述后面。

segments.en: Okay, so yes, I do live in Shanghai, how about you?
segments.cn: 好的，所以是的，我确实住在上海，你呢？

segments.en: That means, do you live in Shanghai?
segments.cn: 这意味着，你住在上海吗？

segments.en: Right.
If I say, I would like to eat a hamburger and French fries, how about you?
segments.cn: 如果我说，我想吃一个汉堡和薯条，你呢？

segments.en: How about you?
What would you like to eat?
Exactly.
So remember, that's the way that you use how about.
segments.cn: 所以记住，这就是你使用“你呢”的方式。

segments.en: Never say how about your weekend, or how about your vacation, and when you want to ask, how was it?
segments.cn: 永远不要说“你周末怎么样”或“你假期怎么样”，当你想问“怎么样？”时。

segments.en: Don't say that.
No, basically this is a way to reply to someone when they're telling you about their experience.
segments.cn: 不，基本上这是对某人讲述他们的经历时的回应方式。

segments.en: You want to talk about yours.
That's right.
Okay, so let's take a break, let's review everything, and we'll be back with Fluency Builder part 2.
segments.cn: 好吧，那我们休息一下，复习一下所有内容，然后我们将继续进行流利度提升第二部分。

segments.en: Excuse me, is this seat taken?
No, please feel free.
Thanks a lot.
Do you work in Shanghai?
Yes, I do.
How about you?
No, I'm a tourist.
This place is amazing.
It's much bigger than I imagined, and much more exciting.
segments.cn: 它比我想象的要大得多，也更令人兴奋。

segments.en: There's so much to see here.
segments.cn: 这里有很多东西可以看。

segments.en: You can say that again.
It's much more modern than people imagine.
segments.cn: 它比人们想象的要现代得多。

segments.en: Where are you from?
Well, let's see, I'm from Kansas originally.
segments.cn: 嗯，让我想想，我最初来自堪萨斯。

segments.en: A much quieter and more peaceful place than here, that's for sure.
segments.cn: 这是一个比这里安静得多、和平得多的地方，这一点是肯定的。

segments.en: Uh-huh.
But I'm living in Paris right now.
Oh, Paris, wonderful.
I'd love to visit sometime.
All right, we're back, so now let's continue with some more phrases on Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 好的，我们回来了，现在继续流利度提升的一些短语。

segments.en: Okay, this first phrase is one that I really like to use.
segments.cn: 好吧，这个短语是我非常喜欢用的。

segments.en: The phrase is from Michelle.
She says, you can say that again, but she's talking about how Shanghai is so big and so exciting, and Michelle says, you can say that again.
segments.cn: 她说，你可以再说一遍，但她是在谈论上海是多么大和令人兴奋，米歇尔说，你可以再说一遍。

segments.en: Now, what does this mean, Marco?
segments.cn: 现在，这是什么意思，马尔科？

segments.en: That's right, so she is basically agreeing with the person.
segments.cn: 没错，所以她基本上是在同意对方。

segments.en: The stranger says Shanghai is amazing, it's great, there's so much to see.
segments.cn: 陌生人说上海真棒，太好了，有很多东西可以看。

segments.en: Michelle says, you can say that again.
segments.cn: 米歇尔说，你可以再说一遍。

segments.en: It's saying, I agree with you.
You are so right.
I really agree.
All right, so this is very emphatic.
That means that it's really, it's more than just, I agree.
segments.cn: 这意味着这真的，不仅仅是我同意。

segments.en: It's, I really, really agree.
The person really feels something about this, feels passionately about it.
segments.cn: 这个人对这件事真的有感觉，感到热情。

segments.en: That's right, so if you go to the movies and you say, oh, that movie was terrible, you can say, you can say that again.
segments.cn: 没错，所以如果你去看电影，你说，哦，那部电影真糟糕，你可以说，你可以再说一遍。

segments.en: Exactly.
That means, oh, I agree, it was really bad.
segments.cn: 这意味着，哦，我同意，真的很糟糕。

segments.en: That's right.
Now, when Michelle asked the stranger where he was from, he says, I'm from Kansas originally.
segments.cn: 现在，当米歇尔问陌生人他来自哪里时，他说，我最初来自堪萨斯。

segments.en: Okay, what's originally?
I'm original?
No, I'm from Kansas originally means maybe I don't live in Kansas now, but that's where I come from.
segments.cn: 不，我最初来自堪萨斯意味着也许我现在不住在堪萨斯，但我来自那里。

segments.en: Origin originally.
That means, you know, at the beginning.
segments.cn: 这意味着，你知道，在开始的时候。

segments.en: Right, so just remember, Kansas, by the way, is one of the states in the, in the United States.
segments.cn: 对，所以只要记住，顺便说一下，堪萨斯是美国的一个州。

segments.en: And so he's saying he's from Kansas, but now he lives in Paris.
segments.cn: 所以他说他来自堪萨斯，但现在他住在巴黎。

segments.en: So that's why you say, I'm originally from Kansas, but I live in Paris.
segments.cn: 所以这就是为什么你说，我最初来自堪萨斯，但我住在巴黎。

segments.en: All right, so Marco, you live here in Shanghai, but where do you come from originally?
segments.cn: 好吧，马尔科，你住在上海，但你最初来自哪里？

segments.en: Originally, I'm from Ecuador.
All right, and I'm originally from Chicago, but I currently live in China.
segments.cn: 好吧，我最初来自芝加哥，但我目前住在中国。

segments.en: That's right.
Okay, so as he was talking about Kansas, he also said that, well, it's obviously a lot quieter and more peaceful.
segments.cn: 好吧，当他谈到堪萨斯时，他还说，嗯，显然这里安静得多，更和平。

segments.en: And then he ends his statement by saying, that's for sure.
segments.cn: 然后他以“这点是肯定的”结束他的陈述。

segments.en: That's for sure.
And this is a phrase that we use to add emphasis on something.
segments.cn: 这是我们用来强调某事的短语。

segments.en: It's almost like saying, this is a really quiet, much quieter and peaceful place, that's for sure.
segments.cn: 这几乎就像在说，这是一个非常安静、安静得多和平的地方，这点是肯定的。

segments.en: It really is.
It's not like you're adding anything to the statement, like no meaning, but you're actually kind of making it more strong.
segments.cn: 这并不是说你在陈述中添加了任何东西，比如没有意义，但你实际上是在使其更强烈。

segments.en: Right, you're saying it's a fact.
segments.cn: 对，你是在说这是一个事实。

segments.en: It's a fact.
It's really this way.
So obviously compared, Kansas compared to Shanghai is a lot more quieter, that's for sure.
segments.cn: 所以显然，堪萨斯与上海相比要安静得多，这点是肯定的。

segments.en: Mm-hmm.
Or I could say that in Chicago in the winter, it's a lot colder than Shanghai, that's for sure.
segments.cn: 或者我可以说，在冬天，芝加哥比上海冷得多，这点是肯定的。

segments.en: Right.
So again, you're emphasizing on your statement, telling everyone that it's very, very much like this.
segments.cn: 所以再次强调你的陈述，告诉每个人这确实是这样的。

segments.en: This is how it really is.
Okay, so that's all the phrases we have for you.
segments.cn: 好吧，这就是我们为你准备的所有短语。

segments.en: Why don't we listen to our dialogue one last time.
Excuse me, is this seat taken?
No, please feel free.
Thanks a lot.
Do you work in Shanghai?
Yes, I do.
How about you?
No, I'm a tourist.
This place is amazing.
It's much bigger than I imagined and much more exciting.
segments.cn: 它比我想象的要大得多，也更令人兴奋。

segments.en: There's so much to see here.
segments.cn: 这里有很多东西可以看。

segments.en: You can say that again.
It's much more modern than people imagine.
segments.cn: 它比人们想象的要现代得多。

segments.en: Where are you from?
Well, let's see.
I'm from Kansas originally, a much quieter and more peaceful place than here, that's for sure.
segments.cn: 我最初来自堪萨斯，这是一个比这里安静得多、和平得多的地方，这点是肯定的。

segments.en: Uh-huh.
But I'm living in Paris right now.
Oh, Paris.
Wonderful.
I'd love to visit sometime.
segments.cn: 我很想有机会去拜访一下。

segments.en: All right, so small talk with a stranger.
This is actually a very common scenario.
segments.cn: 这实际上是一个非常常见的场景。

segments.en: If in a bus, in a train, you sit next to a stranger, this is more or less what you're gonna talk about.
segments.cn: 如果在公交车上或火车上，你坐在一个陌生人旁边，这大致就是你们会谈论的内容。

segments.en: Where are you from?
What do you do?
Where do you live?
That's right, and you don't even have to talk about this with a total stranger.
segments.cn: 没错，你甚至不需要和一个完全陌生的人谈论这些。

segments.en: You could actually use this with someone that you're working with or, you know, just an acquaintance.
segments.cn: 你实际上可以和你工作的同事或只是一个熟人谈论这些。

segments.en: So basically these are key questions that you would ask someone that you don't really know very well.
segments.cn: 所以基本上这些是你会问一个你不太熟悉的人的关键问题。

segments.en: That's right.
And as you can see, you're not really going into any deep personal questions.
segments.cn: 正如你所看到的，你并没有深入到任何个人问题。

segments.en: It's very light conversation, very brief as well.
segments.cn: 这是一种非常轻松的对话，也非常简短。

segments.en: That's right.
And I would like to add that in American culture, people often think it's very rude to ask someone, how much do you earn?
segments.cn: 我想补充的是，在美国文化中，人们常常认为问别人你赚多少钱是非常无礼的。

segments.en: How much is your apartment?
How much is your car?
So, you know, in small talk in American culture, and I think a lot of Western cultures, we don't talk about money or religion.
segments.cn: 所以，在美国文化的闲聊中，我认为在许多西方文化中，我们不谈论金钱或宗教。

segments.en: So what religion are you?
So I think it's important to talk about things that are very, very simple.
segments.cn: 所以我认为谈论一些非常简单的事情是很重要的。

segments.en: You know, what do you do for a living?
segments.cn: 你知道，你的职业是什么？

segments.en: Where do you live?
How's the weather, these things?
Yes, yes, this is exactly, I think, one of the main points that when you're learning a language such as English, not only to understand the language, but also the culture.
segments.cn: 是的，是的，我认为这正是当你学习像英语这样的语言时，了解语言的同时也要了解文化的主要要点之一。

segments.en: It's very, very different, especially, for example, in Asian cultures where it's no big deal if you go to the hairdresser and the hairdresser asks you how much you earn.
segments.cn: 这非常非常不同，尤其是在亚洲文化中，如果你去理发店，理发师问你赚多少钱，这并不是什么大事。

segments.en: But in the United States or many Western countries, it's not something that you talk about your salary or that you really ask.
segments.cn: 但在美国或许多西方国家，谈论你的薪水或真正询问这些并不是常见的事情。

segments.en: It's kind of personal information.
It is.
And if you talk about it, you might make people very uncomfortable.
segments.cn: 如果你谈论这些，可能会让人感到非常不舒服。

segments.en: And so I recommend talking about some of the things that we've discussed here and some of the things that we've discussed in other lessons in this series about small talk.
segments.cn: 所以我建议谈论我们在这里讨论的一些事情，以及我们在这个系列的其他课程中讨论的一些闲聊内容。

segments.en: That's right.
And if you have any questions or any comments about this lesson, you can come and visit us at EnglishPod.com.
segments.cn: 如果你对这节课有任何问题或评论，可以来访问我们的网站 EnglishPod.com。

segments.en: We hope to see you guys there.
segments.cn: 我们希望在那里见到你们。

segments.en: Until next time.
Bye.
Bye.
